Gay Problems...
SECTION 553: Every person convicted of the crime of sodomy
shall be sentenced to the penitentiary for not less than one year nor
more than ten years.
SECTION 554: Every person who shall be convicted of taking into
his or her mouth the sexual organ ofany other person or animal, or
who shall be convicted of placing his or her sexual organ in the
mouth of any other person or animal, or who shall be convicted of
committing any other unnatural or perverted sexual practice with
any other person or animal, shall be fined not more than one thousand dollars, or be imprisoned in jail or in the penitentiary for a
period not exceeding ten years, or shall be both fined and imprisoned within the limits above prescribed in the discretion of the Court.
--From the Maryland Criminal Code

The above law, and the attitude it represents, is
insane. It is just the legal embodiment,however, of a fear
and hatred that is rooted deep in the heart of all those
who consider themselves "straight." The homosexual,
pictured in our minds as some horrible, swishing,
lisping, child-molesting beast, is someone we find too
threatening to accept. He is a reminder of sexual crosscurrents we would prefer to keep buried, and so he
stands as an attack on our most cherished selfperceptions.
At best, he receives an amused tolerance from those
who like to consider themselves enlightened. But more
often, he finds himself subject to harassment and
jailings and beatings. That is the reality of homosexual
life. When the jokes about hair-dressers and balletdancers are over, there remains only the harsh
desperation of gay bars. Relationships are brief; often,
there is merely loneliness.
The warped and brutal tactics of police are not the
only source of trouble for the homosexual. The cop who
entraps gay people finds his support in the acquiesence
of otherwise progressive people. And this University, in
its coldness and hostility, has helped make the life of the
homosexual here quite miserable.

...Some Suggestions
We at Hopkins and the general society have to make
changes in our attitude and conduct towards gay people.
At the very least, all restraints on the sexual conduct of
the consenting adults must be removed. The Maryland
Commission on Criminal Law has made some promising
steps in that direction, with proposals for a new law that
would not ban:(1) homosexual activity between two
consenting adults in private, or between a person who
has recently passed into adulthood and a minor near to
him in age, and (2) soliciting a decoy policeman without
mention of money. But the proposed law does nothing
about changing the present laws, which permit police
entrapment and crackdowns on public displays of
homosexuality.
The University, too, should show a greater tolerance
and concern for the unique problems of the homosexual
student. Following the lead of such schools as Cornell
and Columbia, the needs of gay people could begin to be
met by dances, special lounges and some courses on
areas of homosexual concern. And the radical students
here, so willing to fight for different causes, would do
well to also concern themselves with the repression that
constantly faces homosexuals.
But most of all, we have to work on ourselves, to
change our inner fears, so that epithets like "fag" and
"dyke" have no place in the decades ahead.

what I could envisage over the next several
years. Present plans extend only to three
possible appointments for 1971-72.

lacking departmental equivalents in the other
academic divisions of the University.

marks,that "the Academic Council has no say
in the hiring of new professors." I did say that
the formal responsibility for recommending
academic appointments and promotions rests
with the Advisory Board of the Evening
College, acting in each case with the help of an
ad hoc faculty committee drawn from the daytime academic divisions.
I also pointed out that the criteria agreed by
the Evening College Advisory Board include
academic qualifications equivalent to those in
other academic divisions, and that some
mechanism of coordination was therefore
entirely appropriate, not only with the
Academic Council of Arts and Sciences but

also with the Advisory Boards of the Schools
of Hygiene and of Medicine, if the Evening
College develops graduate programs in the
health field - a quite likely prospect.

statement to your reporter that in response to
the Academic Council resolution (with which I
have no "dispute"), I was in process of
establishing an ad hoc committee chaired by
the Acting Provost and including three
members each from the Academic Council
and the Evening College Advisory Board,
together with the two Deans, to recommend
the best ways of achieving such coordination.

appointments would be limited to "nontenured assistant professors." I said that the

at the rank of assistant professor or associate
professor without tenure, but this fact does not
preclude future appointments or promotions
to tenured rank.

your editorial makes a slashing attack on
imaginary windmills. There is no "come hell

or implicit, and there is no five-year
recruitment and financial plan entailing the
risks you imagine.

The circus is in town. This year it's the red

the most astounding, the most incredible, the
most amazing act you'll ever see- Gunter
Gabel-Williams will now control a herd of 15

gentlemen
And here comes this incredible parade of

Dolly or something equally insane...and old
Gunter yells "Arriba," and all the elephants
sort of stand up on each other's backs;
thunderous applause ensues.
The trapeze acts are probably the most

and shake hands, tigers on their hindquarters,

distinguish them from humans.
Circus people live in a world which is at

colored lights, astride the elephants and
bedecked as bumbling clowns, you find people
of every type.

separate appearances during the show,
hardly a leisurely pace. Yet there they are,
waiting for the next entrance...some smoke
cigarettes and talk, some simply rest,
exhausted, and one incredible girl uses the
spare moments to catch up on her reading.
Friday afternoon we saw her reading
Yevtushenko, apparently digging it despite
the constant interuption of wide-eyed children
wanting an autograph from a "real clown."
Downstairs is the domain of the animals and
keepers, a sea of smells, alive with organized
confusion. "Do the animals all get along
together?" we naively asked one keeper.
"Shit no man, you should-a been here last
week. We had a 200 pound pony givin' this
camel hell."
That seemed to sum it up.

Gay Problems...
SECTION 553: Every person convicted of the crime of sodomy
shall be sentenced to the penitentiary for not less than one year nor
more than ten years.
SECTION 554: Every person who shall be convicted of taking into
his or her mouth the sexual organ ofany other person or animal, or
who shall be convicted of placing his or her sexual organ in the
mouth of any other person or animal, or who shall be convicted of
committing any other unnatural or perverted sexual practice with
any other person or animal, shall be fined not more than one thousand dollars, or be imprisoned in jail or in the penitentiary for a
period not exceeding ten years, or shall be both fined and imprisoned within the limits above prescribed in the discretion of the Court.
--From the Maryland Criminal Code

The above law, and the attitude it represents, is
insane. It is just the legal embodiment,however, of a fear
and hatred that is rooted deep in the heart of all those
who consider themselves "straight." The homosexual,
pictured in our minds as some horrible, swishing,
lisping, child-molesting beast, is someone we find too
threatening to accept. He is a reminder of sexual crosscurrents we would prefer to keep buried, and so he
stands as an attack on our most cherished selfperceptions.
At best, he receives an amused tolerance from those
who like to consider themselves enlightened. But more
often, he finds himself subject to harassment and
jailings and beatings. That is the reality of homosexual
life. When the jokes about hair-dressers and balletdancers are over, there remains only the harsh
desperation of gay bars. Relationships are brief; often,
there is merely loneliness.
The warped and brutal tactics of police are not the
only source of trouble for the homosexual. The cop who
entraps gay people finds his support in the acquiesence
of otherwise progressive people. And this University, in
its coldness and hostility, has helped make the life of the
homosexual here quite miserable.

...Some Suggestions
We at Hopkins and the general society have to make
changes in our attitude and conduct towards gay people.
At the very least, all restraints on the sexual conduct of
the consenting adults must be removed. The Maryland
Commission on Criminal Law has made some promising
steps in that direction, with proposals for a new law that
would not ban:(1) homosexual activity between two
consenting adults in private, or between a person who
has recently passed into adulthood and a minor near to
him in age, and (2) soliciting a decoy policeman without
mention of money. But the proposed law does nothing
about changing the present laws, which permit police
entrapment and crackdowns on public displays of
homosexuality.
The University, too, should show a greater tolerance
and concern for the unique problems of the homosexual
student. Following the lead of such schools as Cornell
and Columbia, the needs of gay people could begin to be
met by dances, special lounges and some courses on
areas of homosexual concern. And the radical students
here, so willing to fight for different causes, would do
well to also concern themselves with the repression that
constantly faces homosexuals.
But most of all, we have to work on ourselves, to
change our inner fears, so that epithets like "fag" and
"dyke" have no place in the decades ahead.
